pullRequest.body:
A PR analogous to #13166.  The reason some of these `refine'` are now caught is that my previous script missed all instances.  I am not sure why it is still missing other `refine'`.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: !bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/0003b5d8-660e-424f-ac56-432318cb36e3) for commit 89f6e9110774b7f2d6c68ce9fe4846fdcbd3e812.
There were [no significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/337f4156-7bd7-4932-951a-44498907b6a3/to/0003b5d8-660e-424f-ac56-432318cb36e3) against commit 1bc0ae3de222be5c5d20098318cc88119f316b41.
Matt, thanks for the review!  Somewhere, I must have done something wrong with a git commit.  I'm about to get into a plane, but will fix/answer later tonight!

I took the liberty to push a commit replacing a handful of `refine` (in files modified) with apply.
For the fun, I also took a look at some of the remaining instance, by hand: quite a few were removable - and sometimes it's not obvious to me why the script would not find them.

Feel free to revert any or all changes you disagree with.
bors d+

:v: adomani can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

Since bors is free after the current batch.

bors r+ p=37
:-1: Rejected by label
Mmm, the conflict is solved, isn't it?
Should be, let me try again to merge master

Yes, I just pulled and merged origin/master with no conflicts.  Should I push again?

(Also, the label is there, but GitHub shows no conflicts, nor can I see them locally.)
I don't see any conflict, so I removed the label by hand.
bors r+ p=37
Ops, this stopped the current batch, I didn't realize bors works like this. Not very serious anyway.
Oh, this is going to be very quick, though, since the cache that it build was already essentially equal to the one on master.  In fact, it is already in the testing phase.
Once this is merged, I'll merge master on the other one and push again.

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9301319981/job/25599195039)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9301319981/job/25599195323)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9301319981/job/25599196020)
Other than Matt's comments this looks correct.
Other than Matt's comments this looks correct.

I've read through it all and confirmed that all this PR does is replacing refine' by refine.
(and sometimes `refine stuff ?_` by `apply stuff`, where `stuff` could be several arguments).

(And `Mathlib/Algebra/BigOperators/Group/Multiset.lean`, and comment-only change.)
Benchmarking was neutral (though doesn't include the last batch); if any performance surprises come up, the last commit is easy to revert.

maintainer merge
Is this one removable?
I checked: it isn't.
This one also?

This one, however, is:
```suggestion
  refine Equiv.ofPreimageEquiv ?_, fun a => Equiv.ofPreimageEquiv_map _ _
Backwards?

```suggestion
    refine J, ?_, ?_, ?_
The refine' below is *not* removable; could this be the source of the error (that *all* `refine'`s in that proof were reverted)?
This is not a good sign. Metavariable shenanigans might be happening here

To follow up on this: this change is now removed from the diff: the diff in that file looks entirely reasonable.

It's very possible meta-variable shenanigans happen here - but my impression is that the current change should not perturb them.
I feel like this should be `apply` (or perhaps we should discuss deprecating `apply` in favor of `refine`).
Also `apply`, although I'm going to stop mentioning it now.
I think we should let this decision fall on the proof author, and accept both `apply f` and `refine f ?_` in Mathlib.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - chore: more `refine'` to `refine`

nodes.body: !bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/0003b5d8-660e-424f-ac56-432318cb36e3) for commit 89f6e9110774b7f2d6c68ce9fe4846fdcbd3e812.
There were [no significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/337f4156-7bd7-4932-951a-44498907b6a3/to/0003b5d8-660e-424f-ac56-432318cb36e3) against commit 1bc0ae3de222be5c5d20098318cc88119f316b41.
Matt, thanks for the review!  Somewhere, I must have done something wrong with a git commit.  I'm about to get into a plane, but will fix/answer later tonight!
Other than Matt's comments this looks correct.

I took the liberty to push a commit replacing a handful of `refine` (in files modified) with apply.
For the fun, I also took a look at some of the remaining instance, by hand: quite a few were removable - and sometimes it's not obvious to me why the script would not find them.

Feel free to revert any or all changes you disagree with.

I've read through it all and confirmed that all this PR does is replacing refine' by refine.
(and sometimes `refine stuff ?_` by `apply stuff`, where `stuff` could be several arguments).

(And `Mathlib/Algebra/BigOperators/Group/Multiset.lean`, and comment-only change.)
Benchmarking was neutral (though doesn't include the last batch); if any performance surprises come up, the last commit is easy to revert.

maintainer merge
bors d+

:v: adomani can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - chore: final batch of mass replacements `refine'` to `refine`
